awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Advanced Morphology Characterization of Nanostructured Cyclic and Linear Polymers and their Blends
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description
Over the past thirty years, tremendous advancements have occurred in the microelectronics and healthcare industries, resulting in phones that are more powerful than the earliest computers and medical treatments that are more effective, less invasive, and capable of treating formerly untreatable ailments. This rapid technological growth was enabled by the creation of new materials and efforts to fully understand their chemical and physical properties. In order to sustain this level of growth, the search for new materials must continue. This project supports collaboration between university researchers and scientists from government laboratories in this search.  In one area, fundamental research into the properties of block copolymers, a type of nanostructured rubbery plastic material, promises a new route to lithographic patterning on the nano-scale to facilitate the move from micro-electronics to nano-electronics that are faster and capable of greater data storage.  In a second area, studies on biocompatible, biodegradable, semi-crystalline polymers will reduce the need for undesirable small molecule additives to control crystallization, thereby enhancing biocompatibility and safety for use in medical applications. The project promotes scientific advancement by supporting experiments that can be conducted only in state-of-the-art national laboratories.  By nurturing close interactions between academia and government, the project trains students to connect their educational experiences to the goals of national health, prosperity, welfare, and the production of civically-mindful scientists and engineers. 

Technical Description
The cyclic molecular architecture endows polymer materials with unique and useful physical properties compared to linear counterparts such as smaller nanostructure domain sizes in block copolymers and greater thin film stability. These polymers show great promise as additives for endowing linear polymer systems with desirable properties.  However, the molecular level integration of linear and cyclic materials in topological blends is not well-understood.  Advanced characterization experiments made possible through this fellowship produce the fundamental knowledge necessary to understand how topological blends (linear plus cyclic polymers) can be used to (1) enhance block copolymer nanostructure properties for nanolithgraphy and (2) regulate crystallization kinetics and morphology in semi-crystalline polymer films.  These goals are achieved by revealing molecular mechanisms in these systems using resonant soft X-ray reflectivity (RSoXR) for the characterization of molecular distributions in block copolymer systems and broadband coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering (CARS) for mapping the localization components in semi-crystalline polymer blend films.  Host site visits, in which the PI and students work closely with experts at the National Institute of Standards and Technology, are important for understanding organization of materials at the molecular level and for sustaining long-term academic-government collaboration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE ADMINISTRATORS OF TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: National Institute of Standards and Technology

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Through this research grant, the Principal Investigator (EPSCoR Research Fellow, henceforth referred to as the "Fellow") and her doctoral students established a collaborative dialogue with scientists at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Materials Science and Engineering Division to pursue research on new materials needed to continue the pace of rapid advancement seen in the microelectronics and healthcare industries over the past thirty years. The new materials under investigation were polymers, the types of molecules that make up things like plastics, rubbers, and adhesives. Most polymers used every day are linear, like an un-clasped necklace; the goal in this project was to study how changing the polymer architecture from linear to cyclic, closing the clasp on the necklace, would affect its properties. This project focused on two types of cyclic polymers: firstly, cyclic block copolymers, which are a type of nanostructured rubbery plastic material that can be used in lithographic patterning to facilitate the transition from "micro" electronics to "nano" electronics that are faster and capable of greater data storage; and secondly, cyclic semi-crystalline polymers that are biocompatible and can reduce or eliminate the need for small molecule additives to control their properties, thereby enhancing safety for use in medical applications. Collaborations with polymer chemists were initiated to make the polymers as their synthesis can be costly and time-consuming and was outside the capabilities of the Fellow's laboratory; establishing these additional collaborations included the Fellow's successful application to the Oak Ridge National Laboratory Center for Nanophase Materials for support in synthesizing the biocompatible semi-crystalline polymers.

Although the planned research and travel by the Fellow and her doctoral students to NIST were disrupted and derailed by COVID-19 pandemic lab closures and travel restrictions, the grant succeeded in meeting the RII Track-4 program's main goal of having a lasting impact on the Fellow's research trajectory beyond the award period. Scientifically, the Fellow and her students learned that until challenges associated with the synthesis of cyclic polymers are addressed, their benefits over linear polymers are unlikely to outweigh the cost of their production. Professionally, the Fellow was promoted and tenured within the award period, and her successful and sometimes unsuccessful interactions with collaborators provided a strong foundation in leadership and communication skills needed to lead collaborative efforts involving multiple research groups and organizations, which she has been doing successfully. Examples of these collaborative efforts include directing research experiences for undergraduates programs, serving as division-level programming chair for two national conferences, and leading teams of more than ten researchers through submission, award, and execution of three equipment grants and a convergence research grant. Thus, the primary lasting outcome of this project is the impact it had on the Fellow's research trajectory that is in turn improving the research capacity of her institution and jurisdiction more broadly.  


Last Modified: 06/23/2023
Modified by: Julie N Albert
